persona.name: Casey Buchanan

occupation.title: Lead Carpenter / Construction Foreman
occupation.organization: Buchanan & Reyes Contracting (small local firm—10–15 employees, residential and small commercial jobs)
occupation.description: Casey works full-time in residential and small commercial construction. He runs crews of 2–6 carpenters and helpers, handles on-site layout, framing, trim, and some concrete work. He coordinates with the owner for materials, supervises apprentices, and interfaces with homeowners who expect practical, straightforward answers. He often estimates labor hours for jobs, enforces job-site safety (basic OSHA standards), orders common materials, repairs and maintains tools and the company van when needed, and trains younger crew members in practical techniques.
responsibilities: Lead a small crew, assign tasks and check quality on framing and finish carpentry.
Read and interpret basic blueprints and remodel plans; translate them into day-to-day tasks.
Estimate time and labor for small remodels and additions; communicate needs to the business owner.
Perform physically demanding tasks: framing, roofing, deck building, door/window installation, and basic concrete forming.
Perform maintenance on personal and company tools, maintain inventory of consumables (screws, nails, adhesives).
Coach apprentices and younger hires in safety, tool use, and trade etiquette.
Coordinate with subcontractors (electricians, plumbers) to sequence work on remodels.
Ensure job-site cleanup and basic homeowner communication about progress and costs.
skills: Framing and finish carpentry (trim work, door/window casings).
Use of circular saw, miter saw, table saw, nail guns, reciprocating saw, power drill, and hand tools.
Blueprint reading at a practical level; translating plans to measurement and cuts.
Basic estimating and job costing based on material lists and labor hours.
Basic vehicle and small-engine maintenance (truck, generator, small mower).
OSHA site practices and first-aid familiarity.
Negotiation with suppliers and occasional haggling for better prices.
Time management to keep small jobs on schedule despite weather and supply delays.
occupation.work_context: Mostly outdoors or in partially finished houses, exposed to weather and dust. Work varies seasonally (busy spring–fall, slower winter). He sometimes picks up side gigs (barn repairs, neighbor builds) to supplement income.

persona.residence: near Logan, Hocking County, Ohio (rural small-town, rents a modest single-wide near family property)
persona.education: High school diploma (Hocking High School). Graduated at 18. Completed a 6-month on-the-job apprenticeship through a local union-affiliated program for construction carpenters. Took occasional adult-education nights for OSHA safety, basic blueprint reading, and a certificate in concrete finishing. No college degree.
long_term_goals: Keep steady work and provide a comfortable, stable life for his teenage son until he is independent.
Pay off the small mortgage/loan on the mobile home and build modest savings ($5k–10k buffer).
Pass on practical trade skills to his son and a few younger crew members so they can earn steady wages.
Be healthy enough to keep working into his early 60s if needed — reduce back pain and control blood pressure.
Maintain reputation locally as reliable and straightforward so he can always find work or odd jobs.
Own a small property outside town someday with enough land for a workshop and vegetable plot.
Be able to replace his aging pickup and the family TV without going into debt.
Have a quiet retirement with fishing trips and family visits rather than travel abroad.
Repair and restore his late father's old toolbox and belongings as a way to honor family memory.
Stay engaged in the local church community and help out with the youth program occasionally.
persona.style: Plain-spoken, economical with language but warm once comfortable. Rural Midwestern accent with clipped, steady cadence; drops some syllables, uses colloquial regional phrases ("y'all" rarely—more often "you all" or plain "you"). Speaks at moderate volume, typically measured and deliberate; laughs easily with a near-belly chuckle. Uses humor that is dry and self-deprecating, often involving work mishaps or family teasing. Prefers directness over small talk but will engage in polite conversation at local feed stores, church potlucks, or job sites. Mannerisms: rubs the back of his neck when thinking, taps knees when anxious, wipes hands on jeans before shaking hands, removes cap briefly when greeting elders. Clothing: well-worn Carhartt jacket or hoodie, work jeans, steel-toe boots, ball cap bearing local high school or hunting brand; keeps a pocketknife and a pen in his front pocket. Phone use: prefers calls to texts for urgent matters, uses an inexpensive smartphone mainly for calls, maps, and occasional Facebook check-ins. Social tone: pragmatic, conservative, loyal to friends and family, suspicious of bureaucracy and 'fancy' solutions. When pressured, he becomes curt but usually returns to a conciliatory tone. When telling a story he enjoys concrete details—measurements, weather, the exact tool used.

traits: Conscientious and dependable: shows up on time, follows through, hates leaving a job half-done.
Pragmatic and resourceful: prefers practical solutions and improvises with the tools at hand.
Loyal and family-oriented: puts family obligations first and values long-term friendships.
Modestly proud: values competence and takes quiet satisfaction in doing good, solid work.
Reserved with strangers: won’t volunteer personal info quickly, warms after shared work or meals.
Wry sense of humor: uses sarcasm lightly, often to defuse tension.
Slightly distrustful of institutions: skeptical of government promises and big corporations.
Religiously moderate-conservative: attends church regularly and trusts pastoral counsel.
Mentoring inclination: enjoys teaching apprentices and younger relatives to use tools.
Financially anxious at times: worries about unexpected bills and keeps a tight monthly budget.
Physically stoic: tolerates aches and pains without fuss, but can become short-tempered when in persistent pain.
Community-minded: participates in volunteer builds and helps neighbors with repairs.
personality.nuances: While not highly open to radical ideas or abstract art, he appreciates practical creativity (a clever jig, a well-designed tool). His conscientiousness is expressed in care for his equipment and attendance; he can be rigid about some routines. Extraversion is situational: gregarious in familiar settings, quiet in new groups. Agreeableness is moderate-high: generous with time and help, but blunt when he thinks someone is wasting resources. Neuroticism is below average—he remains calm under everyday stress—but long-term financial uncertainty or family conflicts raise his anxiety.

workday: Starts with a brief crew meeting: plan for tasks, safety check, and any material needs.
Works in 2–3 hour blocks with short breaks; keeps water and salty snacks in the truck.
Takes a lunch break about midday—quick, practical meal, often sitting on a stacked pallet.
Communicates with homeowners mid-day if schedules change, usually by phone.
Wraps up with site cleanup, tools organized, and a short debrief or notes for the next day.

relationships.name: Ethan Buchanan
relationships.description: Lives with Casey half the time (shared custody). High-school sophomore who likes cars and shop class. Casey is hands-on with his son: helps with car projects, drives him to practices, and attends games. Their relationship is close but sometimes strained by teenage independence and limited finances.

relationships.name: Laura Buchanan
relationships.description: Works part-time at the county library. Co-parenting relationship is pragmatic and mostly cooperative; they split custody and alternate holidays. They communicate about school and medical appointments and occasionally have disagreements about expenses.

relationships.name: Mary Buchanan
relationships.description: Lives nearby in a modest single-family house. Casey helps with yard work and small repairs. Mary is a stabilizing presence; Casey is protective of her and visits weekly for Sunday dinner.

relationships.name: Miguel Reyes
relationships.description: Co-owner of the contracting business and long-time friend. They started working together in their 20s. Miguel handles more of the paperwork and customer sales while Casey oversees the on-site crew work. They share tools, stories, and a mutual trust.

relationships.name: Joan Miller
relationships.description: Widowed neighbor who exchanges preserves and garden produce with Casey's family. Practical, blunt, and a reliable source of local gossip and community memory.

relationships.name: Pastor Daniel Price
relationships.description: Local church leader who offers occasional counseling, moral guidance, and community coordination. Casey respects him and participates in a couple of church activities each month.

relationships.name: Liam Carter
relationships.description: Young apprentice Casey mentors. Eager but inexperienced; Casey invests time teaching him foundational skills and expects punctuality and seriousness in return.

relationships.name: Karen Thompson
relationships.description: Lives two towns over with her own family. They talk on holidays and exchange favors occasionally; she is more comfortable with budgeting and sometimes gives Casey advice on paperwork.

relationships.name: Randy Polk
relationships.description: Local mechanic who helps Casey keep the truck running. They barter favors occasionally.

relationships.name: Miguel Reyes (see above)
relationships.description: Co-owner who handles contracts and customer interface; relies on Casey's reputation to deliver quality labor.

other_facts: Born and raised in the same county where he currently lives; his family has deep ties to the area going back several generations.
Has the same phone number for over 15 years and keeps voicemail short and direct.
First job at 14: mowing lawns for neighbors and stacking wood for older residents; learned early to trade work for cash.
At 17, helped his father build a small shed—decided to pursue construction work after that experience.
His father died when Casey was 29; he inherited a battered toolbox and a short note encouraging practical pride in work.
Has a faded tattoo of a simple anchor on his forearm from his early 20s—memorial to a friend who moved away.
Occasional chronic back flare-ups led him to modify lifting techniques and invest in a used back brace for heavy days.
Used to race snowmobiles as a teen with local friends; still remembers the thrill and camaraderie.
Was never in the military; chose an apprenticeship and local work instead.
Took a continuing-ed course on concrete techniques after a botched small foundation that taught him to be detail-oriented.
Speaks some Spanish basics picked up from working with coworkers and the local community; can give simple instructions but not fluent.
Once got into a heated but nonviolent argument with a customer over costs; learned to get change orders in writing afterward.
Has images of his son’s soccer game taped to the workshop wall, plus a calendar with job start dates and local events.
Is practical about technology: uses a smartphone for maps and weather, but still prefers paper receipts and a physical notebook.
Has a small freezer with leftover meals and two emergency jugs of water in case of storms.
Did a couple months of side work renovating a neighbor’s farmhouse for extra income after a rainy season slowed contractor work.
Keeps a modest emergency fund in a locked box at home—enough for a car repair or short gap between jobs.
Has a reliable neighbor network—when someone needs help, the community usually trades favors rather than money.
Volunteered to help rebuild part of the local community center after a storm damaged the roof.
Keeps a low profile politically in public spaces; will vote and occasionally attends local meetings to support school budgets important to his son.
Has a sentimental attachment to his father’s old hammer; uses it for small jobs and keeps it in the toolbox.
Once rescued a stray dog and nursed it back to health; the dog stayed a part of the household for several years.
